By CURT ZIMANSKY
The recent uproar over
cheating in college, particularly evidenced by the Air
Force Academy scandal,
shouldn't affect the estimation of the Hopkins System,
according to Don Henderson,
Chairman of the Honor Comm ission.
In an interview this week,
Henderson emphasized, "It
doesn't have any particular
affect on Hopkins. No real
reevaluation is necessary."
Over 50 per cent of all
students cheat at one time
or another in college, a recent
survey on cheating by Columbia University's Bureau of
Applied Social Research has
revealed.
Cheating Low Here
Henderson noted that this

was "definitely not" the case
at Hopkins. It is hard to say
statistically how many do
cheat, but it is his belief that
the amount of cheating is
low here.
First of all, the number
of Honor Commission trials
is only twelve to twenty per
year. Furthermore, Henderson noted that there are indications that people turn in
violators. And he added,
"Very few of my friends have
seen violations."
No Upward Trend
Fluctuation in the number
of honor convictions from
year to year is common only
because the absolute number
is always so small. There has
been no continuing increase
or decrease of violations.
Another aspect of college

cheating noted by the Columbia Survey is that cheating is
correlated with a student's
major. Two-thirds of business and commerce majors
cheat at one time or another.
Engineers and education, social science and fine arts
majors are also above the 50
per cent level.

But at Hopkins cheating by
major is not apparent. "It
doesn't impress anyone that
way," according to Henderson, but some courses like
intro. chem. seem to produce
slightly more violations.
Violations are not particularly predominant in any
class (freshman, sophomore,
etc.).

The Time has Come
To Speak of Many Things:

In his inaugural address, President Gilman said:
"Universities easily fall into ruts. Almost every epoch
requires a new start." In their respective epochs, Presidents Remsen, Goodnow, Ames, Bowman, and Bronk,
all spoke of change as a required element in the functions of a University. And in our own epoch, Dr.
Eisenhower has given evidence that he will join the
ranks of these illustrious gentlemen.
The Long Range Planning Committee, recently
Initiated by Dr. Eisenhower, has taken in charge the
challenging of some seriously ingrained habits of the
University; for example, the habit of academically separating the sciences and liberal arts; the custom of
undergraduate-graduate academic coexistence; and even
the University's propensity to accept only male undergraduates.
This measured evaluation of the University deierves comment in two contexts. Firstly, in that it is
laudable; it exemplifies an administration unencumbered by the seditious static and traditional webs of
many educational institutions whose major purpose is
to shelter its cherubs from the harshness of a changing
world: an administration capable of lofty considerations.
Secondly, in that it is not unique: this mandate
for change is one of a long string of plans which have
attempted to fit the university style to the new modes
of a changing student. It is a mandate conceived in
perspective to incorporate rather than shy away from
the environment. It is not a reversal of principle (which
might very well be alarming), but an alteration in its
application.
Dr. Eisenhower's Planning Committee has a third
characteristic. It may encourage, by example, the undergraduates to bend their thoughts to the more fundamental rather than the picayune. It may inhibit the
bickering over an inconvenient course schedule, the
bickering over the punishment to be metered out to
two anonymous animal manglers, or the Student Council squabbling over the installation of a snack bar in
the New Library. It may invite more substantial suggestions from the students in lieu of the normal
pettiness.
Dr. Eisenhower, in his long range designs, has
chosen to speak of many things; and we should he
pleased that the administration has chosen to speak
especially of lofty things: the outcome of the University
in accordance with the inevitability of change.
Jean-Paul Sartre, as the subject of his latest book,
almost lamentably justifies his outcome in terms of his
environment; the University's goal, in its latest move,
appears to be to determine its environment in terms of
Its outcome.

Royal Gambit Applauded
As coded Hop gentlemen girded their collective
loins in preparation for final exams, their Goucher
sisters also labored. From the cool, purple broadcloth of lower Kraushaar was conceived a production worthy of praise and a copious note or two.
The January 22-23 production of Hermann Gressieker's Royal Gambit renders manifold reasons
for exhaustive applause, yet most impressive was
its intuitive, dramatic-honesty. It is a quality seldom seen in these environs.
Gressieker had presented his six college daughters with an intriguing, workable script. George
Dowell, Gambit's director must be credited with
skillfully handling the difficult feat of telescoping
what was originally a five act script into a more
Towson-compatible three acts. It was clear that
Mr. Dowell retained a thoughtful understanding
of the play; it moved, as his feminine players,
with continuity, dignity, delight and grace.
The first two acts of Royal Gambit concern
themselves with the moral machinations of Henry
VII and the wifely repercussions incurred. The
third and final act brings the author's message
to the front in the induction of Project Apollo
and the Korean War. Yet rather than degenerating into an Orson Wells Julius Ceasar in modern
dress, Gambit, through the full implementation
of the author's considerable talent, retains its
character. The quality of the play is implicit in
the manner in which Gressieker justifies the
disturbing transition. The audience is never permitted to lose the abiding link it has built with

Henry throughout the play. Though in the complexity of statecraft General McArthur is substituted for Pope Clement moral rationalization
remains the issue, it still belongs to Henry, and
through Henry, to us.
Russell Gold, who starred in the New York production of Royal Gambit played Henry VIII. He
seemed to communicate his enjoyment of the play
to both the audience and the cast. It is to God's
professional credit that he never dominated the
play as he cavorted and hobbled through the
bumblingly-eloquent life of Henry Tudor. The
remainder of the cast recruited from the ranks of
Froehlicher and Stimson et al. included Joan
Willner, who as Katherine of Aragon, with rich
full voice, personified regal and womanly strength
and Susan Rodgers as Anne Boleyn. Miss Rodgers
carried herself with a self-dignity so often neglected in an amateur actors frantic effort to "get
into" a part. Doris Messec as Anne of Cleves
handled a difficult part with success, as did Janice
Kramer playing Jane Seymour, Elizabeth Spear
and Judith Lowry rounded out the remainder of
the royal peerage; both were regal and dramatic
in all the right places
Success of Royal Gambit has given impetus
to speculation that the production might transcend
the traditional collegiate two night stand to appear on local television. If this be so„ then Hopkins
loin girders may be granted a second opportunity
to view a highly articulate performance of an ex—H.K.
cellent play.

The Time has Come
To Speak of Many Things:

In his inaugural address, President Gilman said:
"Universities easily fall into ruts. Almost every epoch
requires a new start." In their respective epochs, Presidents Remsen, Goodnow, Ames, Bowman, and Bronk,
all spoke of change as a required element in the functions of a University. And in our own epoch, Dr.
Eisenhower has given evidence that he will join the
ranks of these illustrious gentlemen.
The Long Range Planning Committee, recently
Initiated by Dr. Eisenhower, has taken in charge the
challenging of some seriously ingrained habits of the
University; for example, the habit of academically separating the sciences and liberal arts; the custom of
undergraduate-graduate academic coexistence; and even
the University's propensity to accept only male undergraduates.
This measured evaluation of the University deierves comment in two contexts. Firstly, in that it is
laudable; it exemplifies an administration unencumbered by the seditious static and traditional webs of
many educational institutions whose major purpose is
to shelter its cherubs from the harshness of a changing
world: an administration capable of lofty considerations.
Secondly, in that it is not unique: this mandate
for change is one of a long string of plans which have
attempted to fit the university style to the new modes
of a changing student. It is a mandate conceived in
perspective to incorporate rather than shy away from
the environment. It is not a reversal of principle (which
might very well be alarming), but an alteration in its
application.
Dr. Eisenhower's Planning Committee has a third
characteristic. It may encourage, by example, the undergraduates to bend their thoughts to the more fundamental rather than the picayune. It may inhibit the
bickering over an inconvenient course schedule, the
bickering over the punishment to be metered out to
two anonymous animal manglers, or the Student Council squabbling over the installation of a snack bar in
the New Library. It may invite more substantial suggestions from the students in lieu of the normal
pettiness.
Dr. Eisenhower, in his long range designs, has
chosen to speak of many things; and we should he
pleased that the administration has chosen to speak
especially of lofty things: the outcome of the University
in accordance with the inevitability of change.
Jean-Paul Sartre, as the subject of his latest book,
almost lamentably justifies his outcome in terms of his
environment; the University's goal, in its latest move,
appears to be to determine its environment in terms of
Its outcome.

Royal Gambit Applauded
As coded Hop gentlemen girded their collective
loins in preparation for final exams, their Goucher
sisters also labored. From the cool, purple broadcloth of lower Kraushaar was conceived a production worthy of praise and a copious note or two.
The January 22-23 production of Hermann Gressieker's Royal Gambit renders manifold reasons
for exhaustive applause, yet most impressive was
its intuitive, dramatic-honesty. It is a quality seldom seen in these environs.
Gressieker had presented his six college daughters with an intriguing, workable script. George
Dowell, Gambit's director must be credited with
skillfully handling the difficult feat of telescoping
what was originally a five act script into a more
Towson-compatible three acts. It was clear that
Mr. Dowell retained a thoughtful understanding
of the play; it moved, as his feminine players,
with continuity, dignity, delight and grace.
The first two acts of Royal Gambit concern
themselves with the moral machinations of Henry
VII and the wifely repercussions incurred. The
third and final act brings the author's message
to the front in the induction of Project Apollo
and the Korean War. Yet rather than degenerating into an Orson Wells Julius Ceasar in modern
dress, Gambit, through the full implementation
of the author's considerable talent, retains its
character. The quality of the play is implicit in
the manner in which Gressieker justifies the
disturbing transition. The audience is never permitted to lose the abiding link it has built with

Henry throughout the play. Though in the complexity of statecraft General McArthur is substituted for Pope Clement moral rationalization
remains the issue, it still belongs to Henry, and
through Henry, to us.
Russell Gold, who starred in the New York production of Royal Gambit played Henry VIII. He
seemed to communicate his enjoyment of the play
to both the audience and the cast. It is to God's
professional credit that he never dominated the
play as he cavorted and hobbled through the
bumblingly-eloquent life of Henry Tudor. The
remainder of the cast recruited from the ranks of
Froehlicher and Stimson et al. included Joan
Willner, who as Katherine of Aragon, with rich
full voice, personified regal and womanly strength
and Susan Rodgers as Anne Boleyn. Miss Rodgers
carried herself with a self-dignity so often neglected in an amateur actors frantic effort to "get
into" a part. Doris Messec as Anne of Cleves
handled a difficult part with success, as did Janice
Kramer playing Jane Seymour, Elizabeth Spear
and Judith Lowry rounded out the remainder of
the royal peerage; both were regal and dramatic
in all the right places
Success of Royal Gambit has given impetus
to speculation that the production might transcend
the traditional collegiate two night stand to appear on local television. If this be so„ then Hopkins
loin girders may be granted a second opportunity
to view a highly articulate performance of an ex—H.K.
cellent play.
